questions.question: A management's specialist is an individual or organization with expertise that:

options.A: Is engaged by the auditor to assist with the audit
options.B: Is used by management to assist in preparing the financial statements
options.C: Reviews the auditor's work for quality control
options.D: Provides legal services to the audit firm

questions.explanation: A management's specialist provides expertise to help management prepare the financial statements or develop estimates. Examples include actuaries valuing pension obligations or appraisers valuing assets.
questions.tip: Management's specialist = helps management, not the auditor. Think actuaries, appraisers.

questions.question: An auditor's specialist is engaged to:

options.B: Assist the auditor in obtaining sufficient appropriate audit evidence
options.C: Manage the audit engagement

questions.explanation: An auditor's specialist is engaged by the auditor to assist in obtaining sufficient appropriate audit evidence in areas requiring specialized expertise that the auditor lacks.
questions.tip: Auditor's specialist = helps auditor get evidence, not helps client with F/S.

questions.question: When using work of a specialist, the auditor should evaluate the specialist's:

options.B: Competence, capabilities, and objectivity
options.C: Fee structure compared to industry averages
options.D: Length of relationship with the client

questions.explanation: The auditor evaluates the specialist's competence (qualifications, certifications, experience), capabilities (ability to perform the work), and objectivity (circumstances affecting independence).
questions.tip: Evaluate specialist: competent + capable + objective. The three C's (well, CCO).

questions.question: When evaluating work performed by a specialist, the auditor should:

options.A: Accept the specialist's conclusions without question
options.B: Evaluate whether the work is adequate for audit purposes
options.C: Re-perform all specialist procedures

questions.explanation: The auditor evaluates the adequacy of the specialist's work for audit purposes, including the appropriateness of data, methods, and assumptions used, and whether conclusions are reasonable and consistent with other evidence.
questions.tip: Evaluate specialist work: appropriate data + methods + assumptions + reasonable conclusions.

questions.question: The external auditor may use work performed by internal auditors to:

options.B: Modify the nature, timing, or extent of planned audit procedures
options.C: Eliminate the need for understanding internal control

questions.explanation: The external auditor may use internal auditor work to modify procedures, potentially reducing the extent of testing in areas where internal auditors performed relevant work. However, the external auditor retains sole responsibility for the opinion.
questions.tip: Internal audit work can reduce external auditor's work but not replace responsibility.

questions.question: When internal auditors provide direct assistance on an audit engagement, the external auditor must:

options.B: Evaluate threats to objectivity and direct, supervise, and review their work
options.C: Treat them the same as external audit staff
options.D: Only use them for administrative tasks

questions.explanation: When using internal auditors for direct assistance, the external auditor evaluates threats to objectivity, obtains internal auditor acknowledgment, and provides appropriate direction, supervision, and review of the work performed.
questions.tip: Direct assistance = evaluate objectivity + direct + supervise + review. More involvement required.

questions.conceptTested: Reference to specialists in audit report
questions.question: When using an auditor's specialist, the audit report should:

options.A: Always name the specialist and describe their work
options.B: Not refer to the specialist unless the report is modified and reference would assist understanding
options.C: Include the specialist's report as an appendix

questions.explanation: The auditor's report should not refer to the work of a specialist unless doing so is relevant to understanding a modified opinion. Reference in an unmodified opinion could be misinterpreted as divided responsibility.
questions.tip: No reference to specialist in unmodified report. Reference only for modified opinions when helpful.

questions.question: When determining whether to use work of internal auditors, the external auditor should evaluate:

options.A: Only the size of the internal audit department
options.B: The organizational status, objectivity, competence, and work quality of internal audit
options.C: Whether internal audit reports to the CEO

questions.explanation: The external auditor evaluates factors affecting the reliability of internal audit work, including organizational status (reporting lines), policies supporting objectivity, competence, and whether internal audit applies a systematic approach.
questions.tip: Internal audit evaluation: status + objectivity + competence + systematic approach/quality.

questions.question: Which situation would create the greatest threat to a specialist's objectivity?

options.A: The specialist has performed similar work for other clients
options.B: The specialist's fees are contingent on the outcome of the valuation
options.C: The specialist uses industry-standard methodology

questions.explanation: Contingent fees create a significant self-interest threat to objectivity, as the specialist has a financial incentive to reach conclusions favorable to the party paying them. This is a red flag for the auditor.
questions.tip: Contingent fees = self-interest threat. Specialist should be paid regardless of outcome.

questions.question: When engaging an auditor's specialist, the auditor should reach agreement on:

options.A: The audit opinion to be issued
options.B: The nature, scope, and objectives of the specialist's work
options.C: Who will sign the audit report

questions.explanation: The auditor should agree with the specialist on the nature, scope, and objectives of work; roles and responsibilities; nature, timing, and extent of communication; and confidentiality requirements.
questions.tip: Specialist engagement = agree on scope, objectives, roles, and communication upfront.

questions.question: The external auditor should not use internal auditors to perform procedures that involve:

options.B: Significant judgments, high risks, or matters outside their competence
options.C: Any work on revenue
options.D: Testing at locations other than headquarters

questions.explanation: Internal auditors should not perform procedures involving significant auditor judgment, high-risk areas requiring specialized external auditor expertise, or matters where threats to objectivity cannot be reduced to acceptable levels.
questions.tip: Keep high-judgment, high-risk work with external auditor. Internal audit = lower-risk work.

questions.question: When using work of a specialist, the auditor is:

options.A: Relieved of responsibility for the related audit conclusions
options.B: Solely responsible for the audit opinion
options.C: Jointly responsible with the specialist
options.D: Permitted to disclaim responsibility for the specialist's area

questions.explanation: The auditor is solely responsible for the audit opinion. Using a specialist does not reduce this responsibility, regardless of the specialist's competence or the quality of their work.
questions.tip: Auditor's opinion = auditor's responsibility. Period. Specialists don't share the responsibility.

questions.question: When using internal auditors' work, the external auditor should:

options.A: Accept it without re-performance if internal audit is competent
options.B: Re-perform some of the work to evaluate its adequacy
options.C: Only use work that has been reviewed by the audit committee
options.D: Require internal audit to redo any work more than six months old

questions.explanation: The external auditor should re-perform some of the internal auditor's work to evaluate whether the work is adequate for the external auditor's purposes. The extent of re-performance depends on the assessment of internal audit quality.
questions.tip: Re-perform some internal audit work to validate quality before relying on it.

questions.question: When a management's specialist uses entity data, the auditor should:

options.A: Assume the data is reliable if management approves it
options.B: Evaluate the relevance and reliability of the source data used
options.C: Only review the specialist's final conclusion
options.D: Request the specialist verify all data independently

questions.explanation: The auditor should evaluate whether the data used by the specialist is relevant and reliable for the purpose. If the source data comes from the entity, the auditor may need to test the data's accuracy and completeness.
questions.tip: Garbage in, garbage out. Test the data feeding the specialist's analysis.

questions.question: Internal audit is more likely to be objective when it reports to:

options.B: The audit committee or board of directors
options.C: The controller

questions.explanation: Internal audit objectivity is enhanced when it reports functionally to the audit committee or board rather than to management. This reporting structure reduces threats to objectivity from management influence.
questions.tip: Internal audit reporting to audit committee = greater objectivity than reporting to management.

questions.question: Which of the following is most likely to be a management's specialist?

options.B: An actuary calculating pension obligations
options.C: A tax preparer engaged by the audit firm

questions.explanation: Actuaries are commonly used by management to calculate pension and other benefit obligations for financial statement purposes. Their work helps management prepare the financial statements.
questions.tip: Actuary for pensions = classic management's specialist. Helps prepare F/S amounts.

questions.question: If the auditor disagrees with the findings of a management's specialist, the auditor should:

options.A: Accept the specialist's findings since they are the expert
options.B: Obtain additional evidence and consider the effect on the audit opinion
options.C: Always engage a different specialist

questions.explanation: When the auditor disagrees with a specialist's findings, additional evidence should be obtained, such as engaging the auditor's own specialist or performing additional procedures. The effect on the opinion must be considered.
questions.tip: Disagreement = get more evidence. May need own specialist or different procedures.

questions.question: An auditor's IT specialist may assist with:

options.B: Understanding and testing IT general controls and application controls
options.C: Approving management's accounting policies
options.D: Training client personnel on system usage

questions.explanation: IT specialists assist auditors in understanding complex IT environments, evaluating IT general controls, testing application controls, and using computer-assisted audit techniques to test data.
questions.tip: IT specialist = help understand and test IT controls and systems. Part of audit team.

questions.question: When a client uses a service organization, the user auditor may obtain a service auditor's report to:

options.B: Understand controls at the service organization and their operating effectiveness
options.C: Eliminate the need to understand the client's internal control
options.D: Transfer audit responsibility to the service auditor

questions.explanation: A service auditor's report (SOC 1) helps the user auditor understand controls at the service organization and, for a Type 2 report, provides evidence about operating effectiveness during the period covered.
questions.tip: SOC 1 report = understanding + evidence about service org controls. Doesn't transfer responsibility.

questions.question: When evaluating litigation contingencies, the auditor may use work of the client's legal counsel by:

options.B: Sending an inquiry letter and evaluating the response
options.C: Having legal counsel sign the audit report
options.D: Delegating all legal judgments to the attorney

questions.explanation: The auditor sends a letter of audit inquiry to the client's legal counsel requesting information about litigation, claims, and assessments. The response is evaluated as evidence about potential liabilities.
questions.tip: Lawyer letter = audit inquiry about litigation. Evaluate response for F/S implications.

questions.question: When evaluating the income tax provision, the auditor may use a tax specialist to:

options.B: Assist in evaluating uncertain tax positions and tax accruals
options.C: Represent the client in IRS audits

questions.explanation: Tax specialists can assist the auditor in evaluating the reasonableness of the tax provision, assessing uncertain tax positions under ASC 740, and testing deferred tax calculations and disclosures.
questions.tip: Tax specialist helps evaluate provision and UTPs—audit evidence, not client representation.

questions.question: Compared to an external specialist, a specialist who is part of the audit firm:

options.B: Is subject to the firm's quality control policies but may face self-review threats
options.C: Is always more objective
options.D: Cannot be used on the audit engagement

questions.explanation: Internal specialists are subject to the firm's quality control policies but may face self-review threats if involved in the original work being audited. Competence evaluation is still required, though procedures may differ.
questions.tip: Internal specialist = firm QC applies, but watch for self-review threats.

questions.question: Audit documentation related to using a specialist should include:

options.B: The auditor's evaluation of the specialist's competence, objectivity, and work
options.C: Only the specialist's final conclusions

questions.explanation: Documentation should include the nature, scope, and objectives of the specialist's work; the auditor's evaluation of competence and objectivity; and the auditor's evaluation of the adequacy of the specialist's work.
questions.tip: Document: what specialist did, competence/objectivity evaluation, and work quality assessment.

questions.question: Before accepting an engagement, communications with the predecessor auditor:

options.B: Are optional but helpful in understanding the engagement
options.C: Should be avoided to maintain independence
options.D: Must be approved by the SEC

questions.explanation: Auditing standards require the auditor to communicate with the predecessor auditor before accepting the engagement. The prospective client must authorize the predecessor to respond to inquiries.
questions.tip: Predecessor communication = required before acceptance. Get client authorization first.

questions.question: When evaluating a business valuation prepared by management's specialist, the auditor should:

options.A: Accept the valuation if prepared by a credentialed appraiser
options.B: Evaluate the appropriateness of methods, significant assumptions, and completeness of data
options.C: Request a second valuation from a different appraiser

questions.explanation: The auditor evaluates valuation methods used (market, income, cost approaches), whether assumptions are reasonable and consistent with market data, and whether the data used is complete and relevant.
questions.tip: Valuation review: methods + assumptions + data. Don't just accept because credentials are good.

questions.question: The planned use of internal auditors affects:

options.B: The nature, timing, and extent of the external auditor's procedures
options.C: Whether an audit report can be issued

questions.explanation: If internal auditors' work can be used, the external auditor may modify procedures, potentially reducing the extent of testing while maintaining appropriate audit risk. Planning considers where internal audit can contribute.
questions.tip: Internal audit use affects external auditor's NTE = nature, timing, extent of procedures.

questions.question: When reading a SOC 1 report, the user auditor should pay particular attention to:

options.B: Complementary user entity controls that the service organization expects the user to implement
options.C: The service auditor's fee for the engagement

questions.explanation: SOC 1 reports describe complementary user entity controls expected to be in place at the user entity. The user auditor must evaluate whether these controls are implemented to complete the control environment.
questions.tip: Complementary user controls = your client's responsibility. SOC report assumes these exist.

questions.question: An environmental specialist might be used to assist with:

options.B: Estimating environmental remediation liabilities
options.C: Preparing sustainability reports

questions.explanation: Environmental specialists help estimate the cost of remediation for contaminated sites, which can involve significant judgment about scope, methods, timing, and regulatory requirements affecting liability recognition.
questions.tip: Environmental specialist = help estimate cleanup liability. Technical and judgmental area.

questions.question: If the auditor's specialist has a financial interest in the audit client, the auditor should:

options.A: Proceed as normal since the specialist is not a member of the audit team
options.B: Evaluate the threat to objectivity and consider using a different specialist
options.C: Disclose the relationship in the audit report
options.D: Reduce the specialist's involvement to advisory only

questions.explanation: Financial interests create objectivity threats. The auditor should evaluate whether threats can be reduced to acceptable levels through safeguards or whether a different specialist should be used.
questions.tip: Specialist with financial interest = objectivity threat. Evaluate and address or use someone else.

questions.question: When a specialist uses management's assumptions in their analysis, the auditor should:

options.A: Accept the assumptions since management is responsible for them
options.B: Evaluate whether the assumptions are reasonable for the circumstances
options.C: Require the specialist to develop independent assumptions
options.D: Ignore the assumptions and focus only on the mathematical calculations

questions.explanation: Management's assumptions used by a specialist still require auditor evaluation. The auditor assesses whether assumptions are reasonable, consistent with industry data, and appropriate for the intended purpose.
questions.tip: Assumptions drive outputs. Must evaluate reasonableness regardless of who provides them.

questions.question: Internal audit compliance with the Institute of Internal Auditors' standards:

options.A: Automatically makes their work usable by external auditors
options.B: Provides evidence of systematic approach but does not eliminate external auditor evaluation
options.C: Is required for all publicly traded companies

questions.explanation: Compliance with IIA standards indicates internal audit applies a systematic and disciplined approach. However, the external auditor must still evaluate internal audit work for adequacy for external audit purposes.
questions.tip: IIA compliance = good sign but not automatic reliance. Still need to evaluate.

questions.question: When auditing an insurance company's loss reserves, the auditor commonly uses:

options.B: An actuary to evaluate the reasonableness of reserve estimates
options.C: Confirmation with policyholders

questions.explanation: Loss reserve estimation requires actuarial expertise. Auditors typically use actuaries to evaluate the methods, data, and assumptions used by management's actuary in developing loss and loss adjustment expense reserves.
questions.tip: Insurance loss reserves = actuarial expertise needed. Auditor's actuary evaluates management's actuary.

questions.question: When engaging an auditor's specialist, confidentiality requirements:

options.B: Should be communicated and agreed upon before work begins
options.C: Only apply if specifically requested by the client
options.D: Are less strict than for audit team members

questions.explanation: Confidentiality requirements should be part of the agreement with the specialist before work begins. The specialist will have access to confidential client information that must be protected.
questions.tip: Agree on confidentiality upfront—specialist sees confidential client data.

questions.question: A forensic accounting specialist might be engaged when:

options.B: Investigating suspected fraud or complex financial analysis
options.C: Performing inventory counts

questions.explanation: Forensic specialists are engaged for fraud investigations, complex litigation support, and situations requiring specialized investigative techniques and analysis beyond routine audit procedures.
questions.tip: Forensic specialist = fraud investigation, complex analysis, litigation support.

questions.question: When planning to use work of a specialist or internal auditors, the external auditor should:

options.A: Wait until fieldwork to decide on the work to be used
options.B: Consider the timing in audit planning to ensure work will be available when needed
options.C: Only coordinate timing for year-end procedures
options.D: Require all specialist work to be completed before audit fieldwork begins

questions.explanation: Planning should consider when specialist or internal audit work will be needed and coordinate timing accordingly. Early planning ensures work is completed in time for the auditor to evaluate and use it.
questions.tip: Plan timing early. Need specialist/internal audit work done in time to evaluate and use.
